quotes.quote: This is what is meant by last words: they are keys to unlock the afterlife. They're not last words but passwords, and as soon as they're spoken you can go.
The chief problem about death ... is the fear that there may be no afterlife - a depressing thought.
I am convinced of the afterlife, independent of theology. If the world is rationally constructed, there must be an afterlife.

In one sense there is no death. The life of a soul on earth lasts beyond departure. You will always feel that life touching yours, that voice speaking to you. He/She lives on in your life and in the lives of all others that knew him/her.
I firmly believe that when you die you will enter immediately into another life. They who have gone before us are alive in one form of life and we in another.
There is no "next" after you are dead and gone from your own world.
The vision people hold of the world to come is but a reflection, with predictable wishful distortions, of the world in which they live.
We have no reliable guarantee that the afterlife will be any less exasperating than this one, have we?

It is what we see when we imagine what the afterlife must be like: our happiest triumphs, our most sincere moments, stolen from the seam of our lives, a respite just before the onset of imminent tragedy.
Anyone who craves an afterlife has not lived their life to the fullest.
Men long for an afterlife in which there apparently is nothing to do but delight in heaven's wonders.
If this world isn't good enough for us then an afterlife won't be enough.
My understanding of life is very existential. I think that we are our bodies. There's nothing else, and when we die, that's it. No afterlife.
In the afterlife you don't have to worry about looking for work.
Is death the last sleep? No, it is the last and final awakening

Perhaps passing through the gates of death is like passing quietly through the gate in a pasture fence. On the other side, you keep walking, without the need to look back. No shock, no drama, just the lifting of a plank or two in a simple wooden gate in a clearing. Neither pain, nor floods of light, nor great voices, but just the silent crossing of a meadow.
The best way to earn paradise in the afterlife is to create it in your life and in the life of your neighbor.
The afterlife is whatever a soul wishes or believes it to be.
Afterlife exist in the unidentified substances.
To emphasize the afterlife is to deny life. To concentrate on heaven is to create hell.
You appreciate the little details in life once you realize how fragile it is, you respect the afterlife when you realize how powerful it is.
The thought of being nothing after death is a burden insupportable to a virtuous man.
No Christian is abandoned at the moment of death. The angels are the ushers, and our passage to heaven is under their escort.
The only 'afterlife' is what other people remember of you.
In sorrow we must go, but not in despair. Behold! we are not bound for ever to the circles of the world, and beyond them is more than memory.
The yearning for an afterlife is the opposite of selfish: it is love and praise for the world that we are privileged, in this complex interval of light, to witness and experience.
If we can prove an afterlife, then we have less pressure to make our physical life last forever.
After your death, you will be what you were before your birth.
The idea of an afterlife where you can be reunited with loved ones can be immensely consoling â€“ though not to me.
Death is but a transition from this life to another existence where there is no more pain and anguish. All the bitterness and disagreements will vanish, and the only thing that lives forever is love.
My view of the afterlife is that it's made of different levels, depending on how spiritual a life we live.
I believe that when death closes our eyes we shall awaken to a light, of which our sunlight is but the shadow.

Life does not end when we die. Death is a rebirth into a spirit world of light and love, a transition from the physical to the spiritual that is no more frightening or painful than passing between rooms through an open doorway. It is a joyful homecoming to our natural home.
Do for this life as if you live forever, do for the afterlife as if you will die tomorrow.
The real question of life after death isn't whether or not it exists, but even if it does what problem this really solves.
Whether you reach a lot of people or have a profound impact on a few people, their memories of you are your afterlife.
Life is cruel. Why should the afterlife be any different!
Belief in the future life is the appetite of reason.

People think of life as being so sacred and they feel like this is their only chance and they have to do something with their life and make an impact As far as I'm concerned, it's just a pitstop for the afterlife. It's just a little test to see how you can handle reality.
Of course you don't die. Nobody dies. Death doesn't exist. You only reach a new level of vision, a new realm of consciousness, a new unknown world.
